communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER."

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature's Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.
Depot for Egypt : J. McGregor, Chemist.

FRIDAY, DECEMBER 28, 1906

div.head: PRESS AND MUNICIPALITY.
div.p:
It is sincerely to be hoped that the proposed admission of the Press to the meetings of the Alexandria Municipal Commission will he carried, and that at last the public will be put in possession of the actual details of what passes at these assemblies. As we announced yesterday, Mr. Michel Salvago intends to bring forward a motion at the next meeting of the Municipal Commission to the effect that the proceedings should be open to the Press, and if the members of the Commission are well-advised they should offer no opposition to the project. It is considered that Article 24 of the Decree constituting the Commission ("Le public n'est pas admis aux séances de la Commission'') is an obstacle to this proposal, but it really is nothing of the kind, and this supposition is only due to a confusion of thought. The article is simplicity itself. It merely specifies the inadmissibility of the public to assist at the meetings of the Commission. There is not a single word about the Press, and it cannot be presumed that the term "Public" connotes or includes the "Prens," for in ordinary parlance they are absolutely distinctive expressions. A "private view" of an exhibition or picture gallery conveys the implication that the public is excluded, but that the Press is admitted. It may be urged that this is simply a newspaper phrase, and that the distinction therein drawn cannot be brought to bear in the case of official regulations such as the decree which contains Article 24. This objection, however, is quite baseless, as we could adduce many precedents to prove that where it is specified in official and legal phraseology that the public is not admitted, it does not imply that the Press is also excluded. A fortiori, in some cases the official announcement of the non-admittance of the public contains an implication that the Press is admitted. To take only one instance. A very few years ago it was decided by the Egyptian Government that public executions should no longer be held at Alexandria or Cairo, but that in future the sentence of death should be carried out in the strictest privacy. Yet in such a case the term "private executions" did not connote that the Press should be excluded, nor was it ever contemplated

that it should. On the contrary, the term "private executions" as distinct from "public executions" contains an implication that while the public are not, the Press are, admitted to the ceremony. This line of reasoning should convince every member of the Commission that Article 24 cannot bear the construction which the opponents of the admission of the Press to the Municipal meetings would like to put on it. This is the sole official impediment to the adoption of Mr. Salvago's proposal, and it is clearly based on a fallacious interpretation.

There are, of course, other objections. It is urged that if the local newspapers be admitted to the meetings the proceedings will be endlessly protracted because some very few of the City Fathers are gifted with a fatal fluency. Their portentous volubility will, it is urged, be terribly augmented if they flatter themselves that all their orations will be reported word for word in the newspapers of the following day. These windbags will talk and argue for hours and hours in the hope of perusing countless columns of their verbiage in the local Press, and the result will be that public business will come to a standstill, the routine of the Municipal Commission will become out of gear, and the fabric of the Municipality will be dislocated. All this anxiety is quite needless, The small space available for the reports in the local Press absolutely preclude any such system of reporting. On the contrary, the admission of the Press will facilitate the expedition of public business to a very great extent. Members of the Commission who have a tendency to speechify will be checked and not encouraged if they know that reporters are present who will ruthlessly summarise their discourses, and a great deal of unnecessary talk will be stopped for ever when the Councillors know that the outside public will be able to judge of the efficiency of their policy by the cogency of their arguments. From every point of view the admission of the Press will be of advantage not only to the Alexandrian public but to the Municipal Commission itself.
THL GRUBKS IN LAORDONIA.

The Central Macedonian Society of Greece are sending to the London newspapers by their paper, "Alexander the Great," a copy and a translation of the letter which they have addressed to the Archbishop of Canterbury, asking him and the English Church to entertain more favourable feelings towards Greece, and especially towards Macedonia. The Committee state that the Archbishop and many other clergymen and statesmen of England disapprove of the rising of the Macedonians against the crimes and assassinations committed by the Bulgarians, and, on the other hund, uphold the atrocities done by these Bulgarians as legal and just, and bless every sympathy shown to the violation of the Hellenic national rights." We have frequently pointed out that for many months past a most clever and skilfully-worked campaign of calumny against the Greeks and the Greek cause in Macedonia has been carried out all over Europe, with the object of promoting the acquisition of Macedonia by tho Bulgarians, to the detriment of the Greeks, There is no doubt that in many quarters this campaign has met with a large measure of success, and that sympathy for the Greeks has been considerably lessened thereby. To those who do not know the conditions, the length at which the disputes have been carried on has induced a feeling of weariness in Europe, who are beginning to believe that the Greeks are in the wrong, simply because the Slav organs s constantly din that view of the case into their ears. But Europe owes so much to the civilisation of the Greeks of old, and even of those of the Middle Ages, that it will not, we trust, desert modern Greece for Slav races, to which it owes nothing
By Royal Warrant
His Majesty the King

div.head: The Date Tax
div.p: The date tax census now in progress is expected to result in an increase of LE 18,000 which will make the total yield of that tar LE 140,00. A great saving of time and expense has been effected in the present census by allowing the omdebo and sarrafs to count the palm, in villages where the total pomber did not exceed 500. The work in these villages was booked by moawing and very few errors were detected. It is proposed to allow villages having less than 1,000 palms to be counted in this way in Upper Egypt next year.

div.head: THE PENSION LAW.
div.p: The Financial Adviser dealing with the estias mates of expenditure in the Budget, remarks:--- t8 "A new Pension Law is at present in procesa mi- of elaboration, and is being studied by a distinctive

gaisbed form of British actuaries. The first section of their report will be received very shortly, but it will depend entirely on the extent to which the original scheme will burden the national budgetbeheer it is accepted in its entirety or not. If the charge is too onerous, the problem will have to be worked out on more modest lines. In any case, the Government is determined that the Abbas Pension Law shall be constructed on
scientific principles and shall possess that element of permanency which its predecessors 8 have so on previously lacked."

div.head: CAPITULATIONS AND VACCINATION.
div.p: A striking instance of the evil wrought by the Capitulations bas of late been afforded at Alexandria. Owing to the special privileges enjoyed by Baropeans, v socination is not compulsory as is the case with the pative population. Io Alexandria we have approximately a population consisting of 330,000 natives and 70,000 Buropeans, and the number of cases of smallpox during the last four months is as follows.
lows: September, 2; October, 3; Novembar, 7; 1 December, 26 op to date. Of this number, 18

were Boropean, 2 were Syrian, and 6 Bgyptian. Of the Europeans 5 were Boglish. The disproportion between tbe Baropean and dative is remarkable, especially considering the numerical inferiority of the former.

div.head: PROGRESS OF CAPE-CAIRO LIMB.
div.p: Sir Charles Metoa!fe, who has just returned to England from the Congo Free State border, has made a statement regarding the progress of the Cape to Cairo Railway, in which be says:

"The railhead is still at Broken Hill pending the completion of the survey to the Congo border. This survey was in progress when I left, and should by this time be finished. It will only take some four months to lay the rails from the present terminas to the Congo frontier, and this no doubt will be completed next year.

"The one bright spot in South Africa at the present moment is Rhodesia, where there seem to be no depression. The farmers are doing well, a good deal of fresh ground bas bạen pat onder cultivation for grain and tobaooo, and the increase of stock has been very satisfactory."

div.head:
NEWSPAPERS IN SUDAI
QUESTION IN PARLIAMENT.
div.p: In the House of Commons last Thursday

Dr. Ratherford (Middlesex, Brentford) as the Secretary of State for Poreign Aff whether he had received answers to your queries with reference to an order of Badan War Office prohibiting admission the Cairo newspaper "Al Minbar" into Sodan; and whether that order had now bu rescinded, and, if not, apop what grounds 1 it maintained.

Bir B. Grey (Northumberland, Berwick) His Majesty's Agent and Consol-General Cairo reports that the Governor-General of Sadan exercises a discretionary power as the newspapers which are allowed to biroul in that country, and that the giroalation "Al Minbar" and some others is prohibited. regards the question raised by the bon.mem on November 16 last as to whether the Sad is still under martial law, I would refer ! to Article 9 of the Anglo-Egyptian Convent of January 19, 1899, which rods as follows

"Until and save so far as it shall be determined by proclamation, the Sadan, with the exception of the town of Baakin, shall be i remain under martial law." This article 1 not been repealed, but it is, of course, Ol intended to be pat into operation in exceptional cases. Laws and regulations approved his Majesty's Government and the Government of Egypt, and enforced through regular constitute tribunals, are in vigoor through the whole of Sudanese territory.

div.head: ENTENTE CORDIALE IN CAIRO
div.p: M. Klobukowski, the new French Diplomatic Representative at Cairo, made a very interesting speech on Sunday at the Cerc Françsip, and we have great pleasure in giving the following extract, which proves (if pro were needed) that the relations between tl French and British representatives in Egy reflect the amity that has now bound the ti nations in the links of friendship :

"In the course of a visit which I paid bi to-day, Lord Cromer paid a tribute to tie French colony in Egypt. The Boglish Mini ter told me that be was appealing for its loy assistance to enable both parties to profit L the Agreement of 1904 and to strengthen an aid the understanding between the two great nations." | In this connection the "Journal du Caire remarks: "Bgypt will long remain a Latin 000 try, Lord Cromer once remarked, ``and in the lapidary formula his ideas are admirab gomme op....... Political events in even a quarter of the world have made Egypt the auscultating instrument (sphygmograph) the 'entente.' To carry on the metaphor is at Cairo that diplomacy ought to feel the pulse of Anglo-Prepob friendship......

"M. de Richthofen is said to have said a few days before his death, 'If I know the exact state of the relations between Lord Crom and the Prenob Diplomatic Agent at Cairo should have no reason to bother about Londo and Paris.'"

div.head: LORD CROMER CRITICISED.
div.p: It is becoming increasingly difficult for Boglins statesman to do his duty to any subject race without encountering calampies which may well make even the most high-minded abandon their task in despair of being ever understood at home. The latest instance is provided ! the secretary of the Aborigines' Proteotic Society, who has just published a violent attack upon Lord Cromer's role in Egypt. A men who are acquainted with the facts know that Lord Cromer has done more for Egyi and the Egyptians than anybody sipoe Josep and were decepoy ought to preserve him for these attacks. Unfortunately, we have people in England who think no more of insalti and vilifying a great man than an insect do of disturbing his repose.

div.head: CHRISTIANS AT SINAI.
div.p: Among the Tarkisb manuscripts presente by Hanter to the Glasgow University in tl 18th century is one which should be of interest now, for it is a Turkish translation of sobe water permitting Christians to inhabit Moor Sinai, dated 1048 AH A detailed catalogue all the Hanterian, Persian, Torkisb, and Arab manuscripts is being printed. The commencement of the text is given concerning Moa Sipai in the "Journal of the Royal Asia Society." We should think the mapu sori would be a useful one for consultation Naoom Bey Shukeir for his new work op "The History of the Sinai Peninsula."

div.head:
LUXOR HOSPITAL FOR NATIVES
APPEAL FOR DESERVING CAUSE.
div.p: Sixteen years ago the energy and generosity d of Sir John Brander were instrumental in the rs starting of a hospital in Luxor for the relief o
the native population; an institution which
bas been most 800088sfully carried op level outside, thanks to its management and the sap ne port it bas received from visitors and others,
Daring his life-time Mr. John Cook defrayed a * Do inconsiderable portion of its expenses ; and
since his death his family have still maintained
their interest in its working, Mr. P. Cook being an airman of the committee, and the firm of
Messrs. Tbos. Cook & Son being very generous to its subscription.
| The executive working of the hospital is in the bands of the English doctor, Mr. P. W. 1 Saunders, M.B., M.R.C.8., and those of the or resident Rgyptian medical officer, Rashid Bffen
o di Yossut, who undertakes whole chargo dur. making the summer. There are four native male
attendants and one woman who undertakes the -charge of the barom ward.
| The hospital, which lies at the south side one the village, consists of a power of one-storied d detached buildings with wide, roofed-in ve.

randabs, a high walled garden surrounding y them all. The administrative block contains m- the now operating-room, which was added late pylly, thanks to the generosity of some American nt visitors, a well-equipped dispensary, and waiting-rooms, and here a great number of out

patients are received and tended every day. The greater proportion of the in-patients are surgical cases, and the operating room is constantly in request. The barem ward is nearly always fall in spite of the difficulties which always exist in such cases. Altogether some 26 to 80 beds are provided, and these are nearly always occupied.

It must be remembered that this excellently managed hospital is entirely dependent for tands on the donations and voluntary subscriptions it receives. It bas Do State aid beyond a small annual grant from the Daïra Sapien and the Railway Administration, and it has no invested property except the interest on the Memorial Pins collected by the friends of the late Dr. Longmore, which provides for the upkeep of two beds in the ward pulled by his name. Collections towards its maintenance are made in the suburbs at Luxor and Assouan from time to time, as well as upon the Nile steamers, and various entertainments are held in Luxor for its benefit. The Sporting Club is also very generous in the soms it hands over to the committee, and individual subscriptions speak well for the generosity of the visitors.
Bat nevertheless the want of money is al. ways a serious drawback and the apkeep of all the hospital makes its maintenance a matter

of grave difficulty at times. Its expenditure increases year by year, and though we are glad to notice that its receipts are also on the increase, we should be still more glad to see the latter more closely balancing the former. (If only people could see for themselves their good work that is being done here, and the
cleanliness and orderliness of its doing in a country where cleanliness and order are no easy matters, thy would be all the more ready to support such a deserving and charitable cause

div.head: CHRISTMAS AT LUXOR.
div.p: Christmas was gaily celebrated at the Savoy pr Hotel, Loxor. A beautiful 'X nas tree and a

oboe dinner was provided for the guests, and a most enjoyable evening was spent by the numerous visitors, most of whom have pat op for long stays, which proves that Luxor, with its most interesting historical surroundings and its healthy climate, is getting more favourably known every year.

After tennis and toa there met a large party in the church room to sing more carols, Miss Henderson accompanying as usual capitally.

the service went beartily. Nine communicated. of Ilpois kept Mrs. Inglis away, and others were o spending Christmas elsewhere. The average
chorob attendance for the last five Bands that both charges was 24. o The Chaplain bas New Year's Day free this year for any other outlying place and would

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: The Duke and Duchess of Manchester, who recently paid a visit to Cairo, have been cruising in the Mediterranean on board the yacht Margarita, wbjob their boat, Mr. J. Henry Smith, has chartered this season from Mr. Anthony Drexel.

Mr. and Mrs. William K. Vanderbilt are expected to arrive shortly in Cairo, where they will be joined by Mr. and Mrs. William K. Vanderbilt, Jr., who sailed from Now York on the Kronprinz Wilhelm, and will remain abroad for several months. They will be met at Southampton by the Duchess of Marlborough. Tbevoe they will go to the Mediterranean, where they will board the yacht Valiant for a three months' oroise, very probably early in January

Sir Benjamin Stone, M.P., left London last Friday for Bgp", where he will spend the Christmas recess. The member for Buat Birmingham proposes to proceed as far south as Wady Halfs, bat will not visit Khartoum. During his stay in the land of the Pharaohs, Sir Benjamin, who is a famous photographer, will take a bomber of photographs of the recently discovered temples and other objects in and around Cairo.
Mr. Horatio Myer, M.P., and Mr. Arthur Pell, M.P., will also spend the Parliamentary recess in Egypt.
Mr. Prancis and Lady Halon Lacey have returned to London from Egypt.
Mr. and Mrs. R. Talbot Kelly and family have left for Egypt, where they will spend the winter.
Mr. and Mrs. Ceoil have left Roy don Hall for Egypt for the winter, and do not return until the end of May.
Captain Robert Hornby, R.N., has been made a Companion of the Order of St. Michael and St. George tor bus services at Akaba in connection with the delimitation of the Sinai Boundary.
Laws Gedge Pass and Mrs. Gedge have left the Hotel Miramare, and taken op their residence in the Arsenal.
Mustapha Pasha Kamel, accompanied by Mohamed Farid Bey and Osman Bey Goleb, arrived at the Carlton Hotel, London, last week

A marriage has been arranged, and will take place early next year, between Captain Edward W. Atkinson of the Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, elder son of the late Edward Atkinson, of Ashfield Moynalty, County Meath, and of Mrs. Atkinson, of Rockfort House, Kingstowr, County Dublin, and Miss Logise Oliver, younger daughter of the late Jobo Power Oliver, of the Indian Medical Service.

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET. KEARSLEY AND CUNNINGHAM'S WEEKLY REPORT
div.p: Liverpool, December 20. There has been very little improvement in the demand for Egyptians on the spot ; prices are rather irregular ; quotation, however, are raised to per lb, for both Brown and Uppers, except Good and Fine Brown, which are 1/16 desert. A fair business has been done in Putores, and the following are the latest quotations :
Deo. 10.1d Mar. 9.62 Jane 10.00 Jan. 9.61 April 9.63 Saly 10.00

Peb. 9.61 May 10.00 Aug. 9.62 American Futures - The market this week has been doll and inactive, and prices have had a declining tendency. To-day's valaes are about 8 to 9 points below th380 of last Thursday, except for the current month and Deo./Jap. secondly, which are respeo ively 18 and 14} points lower. The device is not great, and is chiefly due to the absence of fresh business. The unusually large movements of the crop, and the stringency of money, have apparently checked all speculative initiative, and unless the Census Gunners' report to day should hold a surprise, we do not anticipate much change in values or increase of business until the Christmas and New Year holidays are over.

div.head: IMAS AT ASSOU AN.
div.p: FESTIVITIES AT THE HOTELS.
( FROM OUR SPECIAL CORRESPONDENT. )

A 8800an, Imas Day, 1906 Nearly every person South of Cairo seem to have arranged his or her 1908 80 as to pass to-day in Assouan, with the result that the hotels are as full 4g in the high s0840n. and greetings between familiar friends are heard on every side. Luxor must be well nigb depopulated for nearly all her visitors are here, and many Cairo folk are also spending their Xmas holidays in the welcome warmth of this most cheertal corner of Upper Egypt, where the attractions of climate can be enjoyed. ed with all the addition of material comforts provided by some of the best hotels in the country

Here from the windows of the Cataract one looks down over the narrow rapids which gives the hotel its name. Rapids they are not at the moment', for the water flows smooth and quiet past the sandy shoals and rob piles of rock which block its channel. Brightly coloured boats are sailing or being rowed to and fro, and many unwieldy looking passenger daha beans have fossils edged their way to the landing stage within the last twenty-four hours. Across the narrow channel one looks upon the barren southern end of Elephantine Island, bage blocks of masonry and a few ap standing remains telling of its earlier history; a modern red roc fed villa with wide verandah and terraced garden pointing to its probable future.

X nas festivities at the Cataract comodo ed last night, when almost every dining table was occupied, and later on a dance was in progress in that beautiful Arabic ball which is the crowning glory of ihe hotel, and which is a larger and more complete replica of the famous one at Meda House. There was a fall attendance at the English Church this morning, when the service was conducted by Bishop Morley and the Rav. Bir George Petherston ; and though it is always hard to realize the significant one of the 804800 amid such unaccustomed surroundings, 'Xmas wishes were warmly given ald gratefully received

The afternoon was devoted to outdoor sports, & most successful donkey gymkhanas taking place in the big court at the front of the hotel. There was a goodly number of outlook ers and of course the usual crowd of donkey boys and their friends were in the latter dance. Most of the young people were taking part in the proceedings, the Misses Ewart, Warner, Danlop, and Willan achieving much honour and glory. After the ustal races and asool prize-giving the gentlemen am used themselves with a scratch polo match ; and as the supply of polo sticks was but a small one, one team bad to be content with billiard cues or any other makeshift that could be devised.

The dinner was an enormous affair, a gaily | illuminated 'Xmas tree adding brilliance to the ball and various other trophies suitable to the occasion decorating it. The menu was a long and excellent one, commencing with Cana: pée de Caviar and winding up with the onho a paradox plum pudding succeeded by Büches de Nord Surprise, when the lights were turned low and at a given signal appeared a row of waiters carrying delicious sweetmeats, soft glow of light shining from the interior of a pink and white sugar dome on each salver. After dinner there was music, piano, violin, and flute providing excellent entertainment.

Among the long list of people who spent 'Xmas at the Cataract may be mentioned Mrs, Mr. and Miss Warper, Capt. and Mrs. Clifford Ball, Capt. G. Harding, Mr. and Mrs. Percy As Worth, Dr. and Mrs. Morell, Dr. Chas. Singer, Col. W. H. Pes e, Dr. O Hastings, Mojur Protheroe Sunith, the M18888 Wanklir, Mrs. and the M1888s Geddes, Mr., Mrs. and Mine Drummond, Sir W. Bwart and family, Major and Mrs. Donegan, Mre. Iwoney Col, and Mrs. Armstrong, the Rev. Sir George Petherston, Lady Arnold, Baron H. Vou Strumm, Mr. and Mrs. Porteous Scott, Mr. and Mrs. Chas Ford, and Professor E Emertoo.

The Savoy Hotel, standing within it go the various gardens at the northern point of Elephantine Island, his also its full complement of visitors, among which it reckons some of very great social import, but who prefer to travel more or less incognito. There is an air of restfulness about this bottle which makes it doubly attractive to those who wish for. quiet seclusion, and its garden is as beautiful As a garden can be. 0.anders, bongaio villas, point collies are there, with many other flowering shrubs and trees of tropical beauty, and the scent of the roses fills the air. It is dithi salt to wander among them and to remember the 00000pt written by Miss A E. Bulwards little more than thirty years ago when roses as flowers were things unknown in A8:00ap. div.head: THE ENGLISH IN EGYPT.
div.p: THE SECRET OF OUR SUCCESS.

"The English in Egypt" was the sobject of a lectora delivered at the London Lastition recently by Mr. Raymond Blatbwayt, the well known traveller and journalist. I. eulogising the great work done in Egypt by Great Britain, the value of wbjob work coo cyst not merely in what we have been polished for the Egyptiar, but also in what we base helped and are helping him to do for himself, Mr. Blath wayt said the msi spring or oar o occupation was our government by character. There was nothing more remarkable than the way we had taken bold of this land, and obliged it to our resolute purpose. The Assosad barrage, which he described as the greatest reservoir the world has ever seen, was bo the beginning of the vast sobame of irrigation which is to be carried out in Egypt which would change the whole character of the country That the Boglish bad benefited socially, mor ally, and commercially to an absolutely incredible extent was beyond question, bo wonderful as was our work here, and splendid as were its results, he was almost certain that if we quit Egypt to-day. in five years' time the country would be romantically chaotic once more, she would inevitably retar to her primitive condition. Bat the Goblet would never leave Egypt, so it was safe to propbosy for her a future brilliant beyond our wildest dreams. That upon which we bad to congratulate ourselves most of all in our coca passion of Egypt was the type of Engli.bmon w had sent ont bere. LA Bzypt, as in India, found the very ff war of our proud and predominant race. "You rale lodia by charaober,' the Marquis Ito one remarked, and that we the secret of our 8QC 389 in Egypt. It was the domination of character, the answering integrity of our motives, which had placed on where we are. The Boglist oocopied Exy, for the benefit of the Nile country, and so long as that motive way predominant the Empire would farish spiritually, socially, intele to ally, and commercially.
At the close of his lecture, Mr. Blatbwayt exhibited a large bomber of beautiful photographs depicting the features of interest in Egypt.

div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EeYPTIAN GAZETTE"
Sir,- I noticed the following paragraph in your is8ue of Wednesday last :

A sad case of death from mi adrentare occurred yesterday in the Attarin quote of Alexandria. A Greek from Pyrgos Angelos loglossi by name, suffered from a severe attack of neuralgia. He called in a doctor to ende his agonies and the latter injected morphia with fatal.

results. As I was the physician there mentioned I should like to explain the facts of the case Mr. Angelo Inglesei was suffering from a severe attack of Angina Peotorie, as we proved by the post-mortem rusmidatior, whiet was held on the day after his death. I could only soothe bid agony, which was terrible, by injecting morphia. Tuis I did with the greatest care, and he did not succumb to an watbio, bot expired from disease of the best This is evident from the post mortem enquiry, and from the door nonton which have been sent to the Hallenis Con late at Alexandria in regard to the one Trusting that you will have the curte.y to insert this explanation. div.head: CORPORATION OF WESTERN
div.p: EGYPT.

An important memorandum by Mr. Besdoell is included in the report of the Corporation of Western Egypt on the saleable value of the lands to be acquired under the concession, from which we extra: the following :

"I estimate that the first-class land will realize £30-£40 an acre, a conservative estimate seeing that land of similar quality in the Nile Valley is worth at the present time upwards of £70 an acre, mobile prices seem likely to rise still bigger. A load of lighter quality should
realize £15 and sore and upwards. | "The cultivable areas comprise alluvial | covered tracts of two distinct qualities : (1)
first-class heavy loam land, (2) lighter sandy load. Where these have been broken up and cultivated before-9von so far back as Roman times -excellent crops can be raised the first year.

Ambo Graph is given in the report, which shows a field of wheat raised on the Cor. the corporation's property at Blue Der during the past winter; this crop was grown on soil which had lain fallow for at least 1,500 years, and which was, op to the time of Bowing, bare desert, absolutely devoid of vegetation of any kind. Most remarkable of all, no manure whatever was used, owing to lack of transport at the time. The ground on which this crop was raised is typical of much of the blood in this area, and is in no way a selected plot.

"The area-comprising some 4,000 acres — on which boring operations are now being carried out is for the most part covered with a thick deposit of allaviał sandy olay or loam, overlying porous sandstone; the conditions are in fact ideal for agriculture. The greater part of the elands has never before been under cultivation, and being dry, bard, and lacking in benar, will probably require on an average three years' motivation to bring them into the first-rate condition. Our first season's operations a bow, however, that good crops can be raised oven from the first sewing. if the land is dressed with only • a very moderate amount of farmyard manure.

"I have no bøsitation in saying that, provided with a sufficient water supply for irrigation, these lands will, after two or three years' cultivation, grow crops of rice, barley, wheat, and probably cotton, equal to any in Egypt, and with facilities for the transport of produce by railway to the Nile Valley should be easily disposed of at remunerative figures.

"The results obtained during the past year have confirmed my original opinion of the potential value of the lands of portion Khraab from an agricultural point of view. I may mention also that a well-known Anglo Egyptian, who visited the Oasis last January, informed me that our first crops were moob better than those he had obtained after three yours' cultivation on lands similarly reclaimed in the Payoom; that land be disposed of at £30 an acre and over, and it is now worth probably double that figure."

div.head: MONEY AND SHARE MARKET
div.p: The Money Market.

Considering the end of the year is at bal and all the banks are holding large amount for distribution of dividend, and for their own use, to show large balances in their individual balance sheet, money is quite as plenty As OAD be expected. No sober minded bogini man considered any rise in the Bapk ra was probable, but members of the Stock I change who have suffered so much during the last few years, and seem to quickly lose thi perves, have been very excited about the matter, and nervousness is very catching a matter of fact, things are in a borong sound condition, 8peonlation is at a low at trade and commerce are exceptionally good and, best of all, the question of gold reserve has at least taken a tangible form, not on the Secretary to the Treasury in Washington but also our own bankers are tackling til matter, under the guidance of Sir Pel Schuster. Free trade in gold 138 proved great a failure as in commodities, although ST Felix Isobuster, ardent free-trader as be is, is ngual with men of his faith, sbuts his ey to plain facts. His admission of the necessity for a change is in itself an admission of the family of the present system. To pat obstruction in the way of foreign exports, as other nations do is the obvious course, and will no doubt ! resorted to. Voloss other nations follow a which, in view of the failure of our free goal market, they are not likely to do, we may follow them. Indeed, the Bank has already to a certain extent, been compelled to do this The remedy of a second reserve of £12,000,001 proposed by Bir Felix Soboster is gait inadequate, but if carried out would relieve matters for some time. The great gain is that the matter is admitted even by free trader to call for immediate remedy.
The sudden receive u de soene of gold domed from Bayport, wbob now amount to £700,000 is still puzzling everybody here.

The bank røturn this week shows that demands for the Christmas holidays have been a big drain on the reserve, and these together with the large outflow for abroad, har redwood the total reserve by £8,096,000. The ratio to liability has receded 81 to 394 poi cont.
The dis sunt market is firm at 6 percent for two months and 5H for three months bills, and loans are being done at 5 per cent. The Stobi Market.

However hopeful the prospects of geier conditions in the New Year may be—and it is generally recognised that these are satisfactory, and such as to justify optimism-there can be no doubt that the present certainty of the monetary position is the all-important factor in the movements of stocks and shares. This may be due to the fact that the string evoy and the consequent stiff rates have continued much longer than was anticipated ; and, after all, when it is found that in the penultimate return of the year there is shown a decrease in the Bank's reserve of three million, it is perhaps Doctoral that investors are exceptionally cautions

Pessimism has been considerably accentuated by the action of the Reicha bank in raising its rate of discount to 7 per cent., and this and the rumours of fortber large calls for Egypt, Booth America, and lodia pointed to the possibility that the directors of the Book of Bogland would follow suit, and pot op their rate to the above figure, but the disturbance which, at this time, would this have been used in trade pointed the other way.

Jo view of the nervousness of the House, it is needless to say that business is practically at a standstill. The appointment that no change bad been made in the Bank rate was yesterday received wii relief, and for a time the tone of markets improved, but they speedily dropped back into a state of idleness.

To-day the spirit of Christmve is over all, and dealers are in a holiday mood. As we have Baid before, members of the Stock Exchange are consistent observers of festivals, and all through the announcement that the House" would be open on Monday bus been somewhat of a disappointment to many, still it is already apparent that they intend to make this 'Xmas a merry one, in anticipation of the better and more prosperous' times which, we hope, will come in the New Year. Consol.

Gilt-edged securities have been work in consequence of the stringency of money and fears of a 7 percent. Bank rate. Yesterday Consols rallied to 867 after the Bank rate decísion, buy Feliway again, and at the close were
lower at 86. To-day they leave off at *514 for cash and 86d for the January Account. Foreign Bonds.

International securities are quiet, and the changes slight. Egyptian Unified were a good point yesterday and gained a quarter at 10"}, bat Japan Poute lost at 881 R183ian bondo have bagged. The Pools are now quoted 771 and the New Lives ! discount. Home Ralls

The official appointment that a working arrangement has been made between the railway companies being termini in Liverpool whereby freight receipt of goods from that centre will be pooled together with the publication of a good batch of traffic returns failed to impart animation to this section. This is due to the influence of money troubleshooting 0108. The prospect of gratifying Christmas taking have been equally ignored. Sootcb stocks have been depressed op rumours of more labour troubles, but the later state ment that there was no foundation for ti reports has caused the tone to be less pessimistic. Today the stocks of the heavy i have been weak
With last week's traffic gain of £1,762, an aggregate increase of the North East Company's takings for the half-year is bron op to £353,69, while the Great Western
is £132,600 and the North Bastard £139,0 nts Americans. wn! Stocks and shares in the American mar bal have been doll, in consequence of monet fol

been a steady falling away in prices. Yesterday there was a slight improvement in some din tione, bot in the main the tone was do Southern Railway Preferred gainer, there were advances of in Baltimore Ohio, Chicago, Great Weston, Pennsylvania

Le Caire. et sous double enveloppe, l'intérieure portant la gogoription suivante :
"Offre pour charbon de Coke."
L'Administration ne s'engage pas à accepter l'offre la plus basse, ni à donner suite aux 800 missione présentées, et elle se réserve le droit de diviser la commande.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: A part la Cassa di Sconto et le Comptoi donnent lieu à un mouvement assez con rable, l'ensemble de la boite est générale en baisse. L'Investment, l'Urbaine, la Buil Lande et le Crédit Franco-Égyptien sot 1 bobangés, quoique dans des proportions restreintes. Sar le reste, peu ou pas d'affa On attribue la réaction à la rareté persist dos capitaux qui forme les acheteurs à l'abri tion.

La Cassa di santo monte de 279 1 283 1/2 l'ancienne et de 274 à 378 1A nouvelle. Le Comptoir gagne 1/8 à 8 l'action ; quant la part de fondateur, eli consolide à 92 1/2. La Building Lands ficie de 3/16 à 5 11/16.
Ea ba 089e également la Pilatare de 3 13/16, et l'Obligation ancienne Crédit Fun de 338 à 339.

Par contre, la National Bank réaction de 28 7/16 à 28 3/8, la Bévéra de 49 1/8 à 42 la Privilégiée Bière da Caire de 131 & 13: Banque d'Athènes de 136 à 135 1/2,l'Ordre Khédivial Mail de 39/6 à 39/3, l'Invest de i 15/37 à 1 3/8 achètera, les Bitrate 3 1/2 215/33, le Crédit Prado-Égyptien 6 5/16 . 61/4, la Banque d'Orient de 1: 134 1/2, et la Port Said Salt de 13 9 à 13/1
La Delta Light s'inscrit à 11 7/8 ex couj
Le jury « fait connaître sa décision qu'au choix du projet pour la nouvelle Bourse Caire.
Le travail d'étude des plans et projets A fait très midati easement, ainsi qu'il résulte la critique verbale qui a d'é faite en sence de quelques invités par M. Lasciac.
Ce que le jury a reprobel a la plapart projets c'est le défaut de lumière et la 1 grande distance entre l'entrée de la Bourse le Hall principal.
Finalement, le prix est partagé entre le pr "Vox populi" (projet français) et le P. Cei qui saps remplir toutes les condition, de gramme peuvent être aisément modifiés.
Une mention spéciale a été décernée projet "Naocia" qui est très étudié, très i mais ne répond pas à diverses exigences pr 2008.
Anoun des projets ne peut être exécuté p le prix de 40,000 Lit. qui a été fixé. Lo de devra dopo être modifié.
Jason's son dernier moment, il sera dit la Corporation se rendra ridicule, cette ci monie de distribution de prix et de ment est là pour corroborer nos dires.

Alors que son existence est condamnée que ses jours sont comptés, elle s'amase, prême inoonsojenog on insoucianoo, à déceri des récompenses à des projets qui ne recevrez jamais exécution. Tous commentaires seraient superflus.
Requiescat in pace.
Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
NOTES ET CRITIQUES

Le Caire, 27 Décembre 1906 La desrosiers cours de Londres, datant samedi passé, indiquent une baisse de sur le Consolidé anglais à 86 1/8, de 1/4 la National Bank of Egypt à 29 3/4 et de 1 sur l'Agricole à 9 3,4. L'Unifiée avait réti gradé de 1/4 à 102. Los autres valeurs étaient restées in variées.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier, qui avait per samedi 4 francs à 776, est remonté bier à 78 La Banque d'Athènes s'est maintenue à 139.
loi, après quatre jours de repos, nous avo . 09, ce matin, une séance animés et active. Da BOn ensemble, la ten ne da ma robe a été sat faisante, bien qu'on tassement se soit produit en clătore.

Dans le compartiment des Banques, la N tional a été échangée aux environs de 28 7/ pour finir à 28 3/8. L'Agricole a molli à 9 5. 11/16. La Cassa di Sconto a avancé à 978-98 Le Comptoir Financier s'est inscrit à 7 16/ et sa part à 92. LA: Banque d'Abyssinie a rét gradé à 5 1/2
Le Crédit Pompier a été ramené 780-78 La Bévéra a progressé à 42 1/2.

L'action Entreprises Immobilières et T Vaux, qui avait olótoré samedi passé à L 15, a débuté aujourd'hui à 18 pour mont aussitôt à 30, revenir à 19 1/2, 19 ot otan à 18 1/2, gagnant ai isi L E 3 1/2 sur son pr précédent. Oa soit avec intérêt oos fluo tatio qui ne semblent pas avoir dit leur dernier m La part de fondateur, que nous avions laissé à P.R. 100, a ouvert à 120 pour atteindre 1: et terminer à 120.

A porter également un très bon mouveme sar l'action Express Nile quoi, de 41/16, pr de oldtare de samedi passé, a été demandée de le début à 5 pour olótarer à 5 7/8; la part fondateur a évaporé à 108-110.

La part Bourse Khédiviale du Caire a enco perda 20 libérer : elle a, en effet, débuté à 13 vendeur, pour finir à 110 sans acheteurs.( s'attend à des prix beaucoup plus bas à br délai pour les raisons que nous exposons plus loin.
Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, Nanovib ont avancé à 22 1/2 et les Egyptis
Parmi les petites valeurs, la Delta Lan très mouvementée, a atteint 4 25/32 pour revenir en olotore à 4 5/8-11/16.

A l'assemblée officieuse de la Walker an Meimeraobi Ltd. tende samedi passé au Cai et dont le compte-rendu détaillé a été publ par les journaux, M. Paul Oziol, qui était présent entre son très actionnaires, & fait la déclaration de principes retentissante, que no croyons devoir reproduire religieusement, tol quelle, d'après l'Orient du dimanche 23 L cembre 1906.
L'honorable préside it de la Corporation des Agents de change, da Caire a dit en sabstand

"Il est indispensable que le conseil d'administration soit au Caica; il blå me viveme les administrateurs de Londres qui, dépa six mois, retardent le commencement de travaux; il demande aux administratif | d'examiner si on ne peut pas poursuivre la | administrateurs anglais pour leur mauvaise gestion."
Nous sommes franchement heureux d'enregistrer ces belles paroles du président de l'honorable Corporation, de l'intégrité do quel nou n'avons d'ailleurs jamais douté.

Le paysage que nous soulignons et par le quai M. Paul Oriol requiert si sévèrement des poursuites contre des administrateurs de société anonyme pour leur mauvaise gestion, sera certainement l'objet de l'approbation unanime Il constitue, en effet, une profession de to qui fait réellement bondeur au président d l'honorable Corporation, car il tend à établir, ora toire ment: en premier lieu, que les con viction intimes de M. Paal Oz ol ont été longtemp méconnues pour des esprits mal faits, bon rendement revenus de leur erreur; en second lieu que le penseur, en apparence douce redi raffiné, mais au fond rigide et rébarbatif, de Sucrerie, aussi bien que l'ex-penseur et intermédiaire mystérieux de la Ploughing, a été originellement calomnié par l'opinion publique.

On sait que cette Assemblée, on évoquée tout d'abord pour le 3 Décembre courant, a été remise au 29 de même moie, faute du quorum réglementaire. O., conformément à l'article 30 des Statuts, les décisions qui seront prises
après-demain seront valables, quel que soit le et nombre d'action 28 représentées à l'Assemblée
La question de savoir quelle pourrait bien jet
être la valeur intrinsèque des parts de la 80 ciété civile de la Bourse Kébé livisle (1) do Caira continue à D008 valoir one ploie de lettres par le queles on nous pose toutes sortes
d'interrogations.
| Nous regrettons de de pouvoir, pour l'ing ati

tant, faute d'espace, revenir en détail sur un Objet que nous avons déjà passablement exploré. A988i devons nous prier nos correspondants de se référer à nos Circulaires No. 66, 73, 114, 145, 318 et 327. En les parcourant, ils constateront que, ainsi que nous l'avons
démontré et que, d'ai leare, le simple bon sens ré-
l'indique, il a été donné à ces parts one

india valeur outrageusement fictive. L. baisse de 50 livres qui s'est produite dans les séances de la Bourse de same li passé et d'aujourd'hui nous semble être dans ce sens on prévu de des plus expressifs.
Le fait est que la valeur intrinsèque de la part de cette Bourse soi disant khédiviale n'est représentée que par les droits d'entrée, 8008 locations diverses et publicité.

Or, un de ces jours, on établira assurément une nouvelle Bourse, soit one Bourse réellement kb lisle on gouvernementale, soit une Bourse due à l'initiative privée. Il est, en tout CA8, certain que l'état de choses actuel de saurait se prolonger.
Il en résulterait dès lors forcément une liquidation et les détenteurs de parts auraient
à ga partager l'actif social, soit : lar
1° L'argent qui se trouve en caisse ;
2° Le produit du mobilier qui sera vendu, aux enchères publi q188 ou autrement, soit en ot
bloo, soit par lots.
Le total net de cet actif serait réparti entre les 10) parts existantes, et chaque détenteur recevra exactement ce qui lui revient. . .
Et ce serait justice.

L'Agence Générale du Lloyd Autrichien d'Alexandrie a l'honneur de porter à la con 0- naissance de oblio que, par disposition de

l'Administration Centrale de la Compagnie, à partir de ler Janvier 1907, des lettre de | Garantie, en substitution des connaissements égarés ou en retard, ne seront acceptée; and guichets de l'Agence que dans le cas où elles seraient revêtues de la sigostare d'une Banque, et que le Connaissement relatif aurait été
émis au nom du destinataire. x De: envois expédié song des Connaissements s à l'Ordre de pourront en aucun cas être
délivrés contre Lettre de Garantie, mais reale ment contre présentation du Conais emeo dûment endos é.
Il est dono dans l'intérêt de MM. les Négociants de donner à henri Correspondants les ordres nécessaires pour que les connaissements
lear soient envoyés en temp; Utile, c'est-à dire, au plus tard, par le courrier qui a chargé la marchan 89.

div.head: Vade Mecum for the Homeward Bound
Picture Post Cards
div.p: "The Egyptian Gazette" Series is the most artistic collection to be found in Egypt.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list shewing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:—
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 14 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers of the P.& O., the Egyptian Mail S.S,. Co., North German Lloyd, Orient, and Messageries Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, Bibby and Henderson Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said can now be made without change in 4 ½ hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.

The quickest through Continental routes are by P.& O. Brindisi express from Port Said, by the Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., from Alexandria to Marseilles and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe. The Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., have also made arrangements whereby luggage can be collected and sent to any address.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves Port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna, and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; here there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Domino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea. No hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza.

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of Lake Maggiore, has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse.

THUN (on the Lake of Thun) half an hour from Berne and one hour from Interlaken. Quiet and quaint; sheltered from winds; just the place to rest and recuperate. Beautiful walks, through woods, and along the lake shore. Kursaal, Concernts, Casino, Races, Tennis, Boating, etc.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND. – INTERLAKEN, a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees, the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

ZURICH on the Gothard route. Direct communication with Northern Europe. Largest town in Switzerland, beautifully-situated on the lake of Zurich. Theatres. Big Concern Halls. Boating on the lake. Excellent schools. The National Museum.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

div.head: SALSOMAGGIORE (Italy.)

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907
